reasoning: The critique targets one specific move in the position: the “in-head simulation” toy example used to argue that in the limit cognitive labor can fully substitute for compute, undermining any hard bottleneck (ρ<0). That point is not essential to the overall case (it’s explicitly labeled toy and is only one item among many counterarguments), so centrality is modest. Where it applies, the critique is strong: an AGI “simulating” is still performing physical computation on some substrate, so treating that as labor while excluding its FLOPs from compute is a category/units mismatch; once total computation is counted, the claimed substitution largely evaporates. The critique is mostly correct, though calling it “physically incoherent” is overstated (it’s coherent, just accounting-sensitive). It is clear, focused, and has little extraneous material. Overall it’s a good local rebuttal but only modestly damages the broader argument against compute bottlenecks.
title: Counting AGI cognition as labor while excluding its FLOPs is units fraud
